Tyler Streeter wrote:

>Thanks for the ideas, John.
>
>I will definitely experiment with random noise at some
>point, whether it's within the network or introduced
>at the inputs.  I'm currently using a continuous-time
>recurrent neural network (CTRNN) with "leaky
>integrator neurons", which has the property of
>producing smooth rhythmic outputs.  This might already
>be capable of doing what your oscillation nodes idea
>would do.  I'll keep it in mind, though.  Maybe an
>oscillation node could be a cheaper representation of
>a whole sub-network of recurrent connections.
>  
>

If I remember correctly this 
chap(http://www.unm.edu/~keithw/artificialLife.html) already mentioned 
on this list used the concept of oscillating inputs. I think he also 
provided the same wave in various phases as a significant shortcut to 
evolving a quadraped walker. I think the the left/right and front/back 
legs can all basically be driven from different phases of the same sine 
wave.

Colin.
